title: tributes-paid-to-great-guy-george-edgar
story: George Edgar, , passed away on September  and was buried on September  at Deer Park Cemetery, Dunbar.He had been a determined fundraiser for Macmillan Cancer Support, raising more than pound, since he was diagnosed with bowel cancer in .His we, Carol, led the tributes and said: ldquoHe was a loveable rogue. Honestly, he was just so happy and happy-go-lucky.ldquoHe never once let anything get him down. He was always a joker and a character.The keen sports fan was diagnosed with bowel cancer before Christmas six years ago.George, of Dunbarrsquos Rotary Court, underwent an operation to remove part of his colon and also endured gruelling chemotherapy.Unfortunately, he was later told the cancer was incurable.Despite that, George raised thousands of pounds for charity through golf, darts and football events.And his love of sport played a key part at his funeral, with those in attendance asked to wear bright colours or sporting tops.Carol, , said: ldquoHe loved golf, darts and football.George was previously involved with Dunbar Athletic Football Club and Callum White, who previously managed the side and is now the clubrsquos secretary, also paid tribute to a ldquodedicated man.He said: ldquoHe was one of those guys who was more behind the scenes and would help collect the strips, the money, and make sure everything was organised.Hannah Renton, owner of the Royal Mackintosh Hotel, where George had worked, described the dad and grandad as ldquoloved by all our staff.She said: ldquoHe was a great guy and a great head chef.ldquoHe took on the role when we opened up and only stopped because he had to stop working.ldquoHe was really hard working and would always go out of his way to do a lot.ldquoHe would still pop back in to see us.ldquoHe was a great guy and was loved by all our staff.Craig McLachlan, who owns Castle Park Golf Club near Gford, where Mr Edgar was a member, also offered kind words.A golf competition, the George Edgar Memorial Trophy, has been created.Mr McLachlan said: ldquoHe was hugely buoyant, hugely positive. He was a character who a lot of people could learn a lot from.ldquoHe raised a phenomenal amount for charity, even with working with us up here. I think in the short time we worked together for Macmillan we raised more than pound,.He will be sadly missed.And he added: ldquoI think it sums him up that earlier this year him and one of his good friends John Winters were going to be our charity representatives.ldquoWe were planning a charity weekend up here and sadly Georgersquos health overtook it.ldquoThat is an effort we will redouble next year, partly in his memory.

title: tranents-landmark-former-co-op-building-to-re-open-in-november
story: Mr Thomson, the townrsquos former postmaster, bought the former Co-op building in  with his we Susan, the current postmaster, and will install a cafe, bistro, childrenrsquos soft play, and Post Office into the building.He told the Courier: ldquoWersquore in the first phase, whichyou like is the Historic Scotland listed building part, which is going to be a brand new Post Office, convenience store, a coffee shop and bistro with about  seats inside and about  seats outside under a canopy. Thatrsquoll be opening in November.Mr Thomsonrsquos plans also include  flats for the building, which he hopes will be social housing.He said: ldquoWersquore hoping the whole thing can be finished by the start of May . The flats are going to be for social housing, preferably with East Lothian Council or East Lothian Housing Association, so really the timelines we have to do together.ldquoWe want social housing because therersquos a housing crisis in East Lothian and we want to try and help people with that.The Tranent resident was also very complimentary of the work of youth group Recharge.He said: ldquoRecharge have been in this building a very long time and Alan [Bell] runs it very well.ldquoOne of the key things that I wanted to make sure of when my we and I bought this building was we wanted to keep them on site as they do a fantastic job.After phase one is complete, work will start on phase two of the project.The next phase will include two small shops, flats, a soft play area and a community hall which will, it is hoped, hold about  people, as well as a kitchen and bar.Alan Bell, Recharge manager, was pleased the charity will get a new home within the building ndash they currently use part of the ground floor.He told the Courier: ldquoI think certainly, from our point of view, having a purpose-built facility will be fantastic.ldquoIt will really be able to extend the work we can do and help us reach out to a lot of young people that we currently struggle to engage with, because of our space limitations.ldquoWith it being purpose-built as well it means wersquoll be able to do more work with young people, so there will be rooms designed for specic tasks, whereas in here, we just adapt the rooms as we can. That will make a massive dference.He also reassured those who use their facilities at the moment that they will not be going away any time soon.Mr Bell added: ldquoThe building is secure and we will have a base to operate from whilst the work is being done. Recharge are still operating while the building is developed.

title: decision-soon-on-the-quay-plans
story: Amanda Chisholm, the independent reporter appointed to determine the appeal on behalf of Scottish Ministers, carried out an inspection of the site at Fisherrow Harbour last month.Lodged by Simply Musselburgh Care Limited, the appeal followed East Lothian Councilrsquos refusal of a plan to convert the former leisure complex, restaurant andsuites into a -bed nursing home.Ms Chisholm is now preparing her decision, a copy of which will be sent to all parties involved and published on the Planning and Environmental Appeals Divisionrsquos website.A meeting of the local authorityrsquos planning committee in June regarding The Quay, owned by Dr Charan Gill, ended with a near-unanimous decision to reject the nursing home proposal.Only Councillor Norman Hampshire, planning committee convener, backed council officialsrsquo recommendation to approve the plan.Local groups including Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council, Musselburgh Area Partnership, and Musselburgh Conservation Society, among others, are calling for the appeal to be thrown out., Musselburgh Area Partnership, Fisherrow Harbour and Seafront Association, and the Musselburgh Business Partnership are calling for the appeal to be thrown out.

title: tims-tales-johnny-moat-forever
story: The legend tells us that so long as the stone sits on the rocks, the town will flourish.It fell in  but was put back in  after a hard time for the town.It sadly fell again a few years ago, but at the time of the film Johnny Moat was sitting proudly on his ldquothrone on the Girdle Rocks.Film maker Marjory Boyle Crooks had been keen to capture the tale on camera. It was a lovely calm and sunny day, perfect for filming,I was halfway through the story when a group of local teenage lads approached. It seemed they were drinking and I anticipated them disrupting the filming.But I continued telling the story as it had been a perfect take up until that moment.The lads paused for a moment then all sat on the concrete walkway watching me and the film makers. They said nothing and seemed to be listening.I was able to complete my story uninterrupted.And as I walked away in the final shot I made eye contact with the lads and they respectfully waited until the filming had stopped before shouting, ldquoJohnny Moat forever! Then they got up and walked away.It was an unexpected and powerful moment for me.My assumptions about the lads had been utterly challenged as well.This was more than six years ago but I was reminded of it when I visited Johnny Moat this week with my wee boy Lewis.We were having our weekly storytelling walk in the Pans, a three-hour period between his nursery pick up and when I have to pick up his sister Skye from the Infant School.We just walk together visiting dferent places, and I tell him stories and he does the same.Most of his stories this day involved a T Rex or Raptor, which in his imagination wander about Prestonpans.So our respective tales were a bit dferent in content and style, but what is vital at this age is that he hears stories and is allowed to tell them freely.I told him the story of Johnny Moat and he said it looks like a whale.As we wandered from Johnny Moat up to Preston Tower, we stopped at what we call the lsquoStory Stonesrsquo.Here a small circle of stones sit underneath a cherry tree, with the tower looming behind. It is a perfect place to tell stories.Lewis gave me a new version of his T Rex tale here. I couldnrsquot understand all his story, but I got most of it.Then he said it was my turn so I told him a child-friendly version of the tale of the Green Lady. It made him want to go and look in the windows of the tower, which we did.The final story began at the old doorsquocot in the gardens by the tower. I explained it was a house for pigeons, but Lewis was having none of that.ldquoNo daddy, he said with a serious face, ldquoa lion lives there.ldquoReally  Can you tell me the story of the lion  I asked. And so he obliged.It was a great story, and we tracked the lion to the ancient Mercat Cross, where the unicorn sits on top of the pole ldquolooking for the lion.Then he spotted the lion on the  bus coming from Tranent.ldquoWill it eat the people  I asked.ldquoNo, he said asIrsquod asked an inappropriate question, ldquoitrsquos a nice lion.And so with the lion having left town, we headed for the Infant School to pick up his sister, but still keeping a look out for the T Rex.On the surface this may all seem a bit unusual, wandering about telling random stories that often didnrsquot make huge sense.But I value this time with my son, and as a storyteller I know the importance of it.Storytelling in this way when our kids are young helps develop what is called oral narrative ability, which gives a child the skills to explain and describe things, and develop their understanding of words and language.It fires their imagination and research shows that this can help with the enjoyment of reading and writing later on, and of telling and hearing stories.That night my son unexpectedly ed to the story of Johnny Moat.I had earlier told him it had fallen down and is lying face down in the sand and itrsquos too heavy to put back, but hopefully one day there will be a way.Like all kids his age, he took a while to process his thoughts on this. And these thoughts came out at bedtime.ldquoThe T Rex can put the big stone back, he said. I admired his total faith in the abilities of the T Rex.ldquoYes, maybe, I said. He fell asleep holding his T Rex which, for him, symbolises so much more than just an extinct dinosaur.As I headed downstairs, I thought about the connection between this day and the day over six years ago when I unexpectedly told the story of Johnny Moat to some teenage lads.Stories weave through us and bind us in a shared identity. But it made me sad that Johnny Moat still lies forgotten with his face in the sand.So Irsquom going to start looking for the T Rex of the Pans, whoever that may be, who can help. He or she must be out there somewhere. Or perhaps there is a crowd of them.The hope is that once my son is a teenage lad himself, he will be able to sit on the Girdle Rocks with Johnny Moat and tell the legend.

title: group-objects-to-750-new-homes-at-windygoul-south
story: A planning application for the site was submitted last month by Walker Group Ltd.The site plan extends Windygoul South to the Charles River Research Institute and Carlaverock Farm.But at a TECC meeting, members voiced their concerns over the proposals.Robert McNeill, community councillor, told the meeting: ldquoIn all my years on the community council, I canrsquot recall us making a formal objection about any developments in Tranent.ldquoWe try to be very proactive to any problems and find a solution. However, I think we really need to take a stand on this one.Mr McNeill added: ldquoI think we need to be clear that it will have a major impact on our community. Not just on schools, or traffic, but GPs and our health, the environment, the cemetery.ldquoI just feel thatwe donrsquot object to this application now, I donrsquot think I can continually voice my concerns about traffic and the impact on the community. I think itrsquos time for us to take a stand.ldquoBy objecting, we are making our views known, and itrsquos a view shared by many in Tranent.ldquoMaybe a lot of people donrsquot want to be vocal about it, but I do think itrsquos an opportunity that we cannot miss.ldquoI do think as a community we need to be sending a clear message out. Enough is enough. The community canrsquot take it any longer.David Forrest, TECC chairman, shared these concerns, pointing out the lack of infrastructure as the main reason for objecting to the plans.He said: ldquoGrounds for an objection has to be that the infrastructure in Tranent couldnrsquot cope with another  houses on the south side of Tranent.ldquoAll that traffic would be travelling through the centre, whether itrsquos to get to Edinburgh or just to go shopping.ldquoTranent is unique, traffic-wise, in East Lothian. You have Ormiston which has doubled or trebled in size, yoursquore going to have all these houses on the south side, and theyrsquore all still going to go down Tranent High Street. Nobody drives into North Berwick or Dunbar through the main street. Tranent is totally dferent.ldquoAnother  houses will all go through the main street in Tranent and thatrsquos the point wersquove got to get across.Fellow TECC member David Thomson added: ldquoEast Lothian Council made a statement about April, that there was no need to improve the infrastructure. However, on the recent Kingslaw planning application, they actually said that the impact on traffic from  houses would be excessive and detrimental to the local community.ldquoIf they deem that that  houses is excessive, how can they possibly say that  houses is not going to be three, four times, worse than that.ldquoUntil the roads are built they shouldnrsquot be building the houses.

title: teachers-time-in-turkey-inspires-her-debut-novel
story: Set in the Turkish capital Istanbul, Dr Margaret Halliday chose the location for her book as she worked as a teacher in the country for seven years.She decided to take up writing seriously five years ago when she was unable to live the same lestyle because of multiple sclerosis .An avid writer of diaries throughout her le, during which she saw the world, she planned to expand them into short stories when she retired.Dr Halliday, , who lives near Fisherrow, said: ldquoIrsquom excited about my first novel being published.ldquoAfter writing three memoirs, I wanted to try fiction as I had completed an Open University creative writing course.ldquoTaking the advice, lsquoyou should write about what you know,rsquo I chose Turkey for the setting as I worked there for seven years.The Belly Dancer is a tragicomic romantic thriller set mainly in Istanbul in the early s.Gemma, a young English woman, finds herself involved in more than just teaching English soon after her arrival in Turkey. Her love of belly dancing leads her into a relationship with the beautul Fatima as well as plunging her into a sinister, Mafia-run drugs operation.Dr Halliday said: ldquoI did not, however, belly dance or get involved with the Turkish Mafia and drug dealing ndash these had to be researched!ldquoLike Gemma, the heroine, I did teach English and visited Termal regularly, wallowing in the sparsquos waters just like her, as well as indulging in the occasional massage.ldquoNow I am putting together a collection of short stories, working title, Stranger than Fiction, about some of my weirder travel experiences. I have a character who Irsquod like to write another novel about but need to work on the plotrsquos development.Dr Halliday has published three autobiographical books ndash Prana Soup, an Indian Odyssey, which describes her travels around India Good Vibrations, which tells the story of a single s mum in Scotland and WWOOFing North and South, which relates her experience as a worldwide worker on organic farms in Scotland and New Zealand.Born in England in  with ldquogreen fingers and itchy feet, Dr Halliday undertook a yearrsquos training in Hastings Alexandra Park, followed by a horticultural course at the West of Scotland Agricultural College. She fell in love with Scotland, married a Scotsman and raised two children while working in scientic research and studying up to doctorate level.She qualied as a teacher of biology and chemistry and taught in ious schools and colleges in Edinburgh.Dr Halliday said her marriage broke up in , partly because of her ldquoitchy feet, and she went to live in Istanbul in , where she taught biological sciences at Marmara University for five years.After that, she taught English in Budapest and Damascus, exploring the countries and their environs in her holidays. Then she ed to Turkey and taught biology at a school for gted children near Istanbul.Her books are available via Amazon.as ebook and paperbacks.

title: housing-bid-at-edenhall
story: Stewart Milne Homes Central Scotland Limited is seeking East Lothian Council approval for the housing within the walled garden of historic Pinkieburn House, which was designed by renowned Scottish architect John Dick Peddie.The site, which was associated with the estate of the Lindsay family in the early th century, became disused in  following NHS Lothianrsquos decision to relocate services to the newly developed Musselburgh Primary Care Centre.The residential development would include  new homes for private sale, which range from four to six-bedroom detached homes.The th century buildings on the site would be ldquosympathetically restored to provide  new luxury apartments and homes.There would be a further  new affordable homes, providing one-bed apartments to three-bed terraced houses, ldquoensuring a wide mix of new homes for Musselburgh.A statement from the company added: ldquoThis will help address the critical need for new high-quality housing in the town ndash with careful planning and contextual design leading to the creation of communities that are designed to reflect the sitersquos local heritage.ldquoStewart Milne Homes intend to deliver a high-quality development, based around the unique heritage assets of the restored and converted listed buildings at Edenhall, including Pinkieburn House, the stables and gardenerrsquos cottage.ldquoCareful consideration has been given to the look and feel of this development to provide a sense of community and legacy.ldquoThe proposed residential development will involve conversion of the listed buildings to form flatted apartments, and extended cottage and other linked villas, along with new build houses for sale where within the site.ldquoThis will be an exciting opportunity to prevent the buildings and wider estate falling into further disrepair, and ultimately bring the setting back into appropriate residential use. Restoration and repair work will be conducted on a like for like basis, using materials to match the existing historic fabrics.It added: ldquoTo allow for high quality flood management, road access and opening the area for better daylight, some tree management work will be required.The site is allocated for residential development in the Proposed East Lothian Local Development Plan.The proposed housing development would be served by the existing access from Edenhall Road, with the existing junction widened through relocation of the gate piers.Gerry More, managing director of Stewart Milne Homes Central Scotland, said: ldquoFollowing our initial public consultation and exhibition two years ago, our proposals have been welcomed by the local community.ldquoOur vision is to create new communities that are fit for st century living, whilst incorporating traditional values and features.Speaking at a meeting of Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council last week, group chairwoman Irene Tait said the last time she was at the site it was ldquoall overgrown.She added: ldquoIt was horrible and dangerous, so it needs something done to it. They have got security measures but it becomes a danger for local children, although theyrsquore not supposed to be there.

title: update-rail-services-returning-to-normal-after-trespasser-on-the-line
story: Scotrail services between North Berwick and Edinburgh have been affected - the .am from North Berwick to Edinburgh was cancelled, while the .am service from North Berwick was delayed -and started at Drem, leaving at .am.Meanwhile, there were delays on the .am service from Edinburgh Waverley, which left the Capital about  minutes behind schedule and terminated at Drem.And the .am service from Edinburgh Waverley was also delayed.A ScotRail spokesman told the Courier: "The incident was over quickly and services have ed to normal."The British Transport Police also attended the scene, and said in a statement: "Officers were called to Prestonpans station at .am, following concern for a personrsquos welfare."Colleagues from Police Scotland also attended and lines were closed in both directions."The person has now left the station."

title: schools-head-of-drama-sacked-following-disturbing-allegations
story: Daniel McLean-Steel, , was suspended by the headmaster of Loretto School in Musselburgh three weeks ago.Dr Graham Hawley contacted parents last week, the Courier has learnt, to inform them that Mr McLean-Steelrsquos employment had been ldquoterminated.Mr Hawley said: ldquoThe investigation has necessarily been a complex, detailed and thorough undertaking, and we have worked as expeditiously as we have been able.ldquoUnderstandably, during this period there have been a range of concerns and questions, and I hope that our personal responses to each have, wherever possible, served to inform and reassure you and others in so far as we have been able.ldquoThe investigation has now been completed, and the outcome of the process has been to terminate the employment of a member of staff, Mr Daniel McLean-Steel.The headmaster told parents he expected questions about the ldquonature of the complaint.But he said he was not revealing any details in his statement ldquofor legal reasons, despite also confirming that there was no active police investigation.In a previous statement, issued on September , the headmaster said that he had been ldquodeeply disturbed by these allegations" and took them "very seriously".Mr Hawley has now said: ldquoAs I have already indicated in my letter and statement of Wednesday  September , the allegations were in relation to behaviours which are unacceptable and have no place in our community, and the investigation has found this to be the case.ldquoI can confirm there is no active police case in association with this matter at this time, and I can also confirm the allegations presented did not relate to current pupils of the school."For legal reasons, it is not appropriate that I make further comment on this.The headmaster told parents he has begun a recruitment process to find a new head of drama. He also urged parents to contact himthey have any further concerns.When the allegations emerged Mr Hawley said he had alerted the Care Inspectorate.A spokesman for the Care Inspectorate said: ldquoWe are aware of an alleged incident at this school and are satisfied the school have responded appropriately.ldquoWe remain in close contact with the school. Anyone with a concern about a care service is encouraged to contact us.Mr McLean-Steel could not be reached for comment.

title: musselburgh-racecourse-staff-raise-2000-in-memory-of-former-colleague
story: Graeme Nish, , was the main joinery contractor at the track and the eldest son of long-serving racecourse caretaker Adam and we Elaine, who works in the customer services team.Graeme, of Musselburgh, passed away suddenly on June  and staff raised funds for Pancreatic Cancer UK by taking part in the Edinburgh Half Marathon and k races. Clerk of the course Harriet Graham was joined by marketing manager Aisling Johnston, marketing assistant Maiti Stirling, hospitality executive Grace Richardson, corporate hospitality manager Emma Bidie and her husband Jeremy.Aisling said: ldquoGraeme was a wonderful person to have around the racecourse, he really loved his job and is he is sadly missed by us all. Some of us have never taken part in a race like this before but we were all fully committed. If we can raise a few pounds for pancreatic cancer research in Graemersquos memory then it will be well worth the effort and the training.To donate, go to www.justgiving companyteams MusselburghRacecourse

title: man-targeted-two-musselburgh-businesses
story: Peter Rodgers, of Edinburghrsquos Parkhead Avenue, forced open a locked office door at Musselburghrsquos Costa Coffee outlet and searched lockers within the staff office. He then moved on to the nearby Poundstretcher store on High Street, where he forced open a locked warehouse door and hid from staff.Rodgers was later discovered and confronted by a member of staff and went on to shout, swear and threaten to assault the employee. The -year-old pleaded guilty to all three offences ndash which took place on October  last year ndash during an appearance at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Thursday.He also admitted to a further two offences on the same date of possessing a kne at Musselburgh police station and to assaulting a police officer by spitting on him at St Leonardrsquos police station in Edinburgh.Sherf Donald Corke granted Rodgers bail and deferred sentence till November .

title: community-to-have-its-say-on-how-70000-is-spent
story: Communities Secretary Aileen Campbell MSP visited The Brunton on Tuesday to announce the Scottish Governmentrsquos Community Choices Funding for  , with the Musselburgh Area Partnership to receive pound,.This will be supplemented by pound, from the area partnership, which allocates a budget from East Lothian Council to a iety of local priorities and initiatives in Musselburgh, Wallyford, Whitecraig, Carberry and Old Craighall.Ms Campbell said: ldquoThe Community Choices Fund puts decisions about how we invest in communities into the hands of the people who live and work in them. We know that communities are best placed to address the inequalities in their own areas and therefore know what improvements can be made.And she added: ldquoIrsquom pleased that there are so many organisations that will benefit from this funding. title: interim-asbo-issued-against-haddington-resident
story: Lee Rutherford, who is living care of an address in Langriggs, was the subject of a string of complaints stretching back two years, including smoking cannabis in and around the property, arguing, screaming, shouting and banging doors and acting in an aggressive manner ndash all of which caused alarm and distress to residents of the street.Despite repeated warnings, the anti-social behaviour continued and the interim Anti-Social Behaviour Orderwas applied for by East Lothian Council and later granted at Edinburgh Sherf Court on Wednesday .East Lothian Councilrsquos Safer Communities Team worked closely with Police Scotland to compile the dossier of evidence which was used to prepare the case against Mr Rutherford.A council spokeswoman said: ldquoWe take anti-social behaviour very seriously and it will not be tolerated in East Lothian as it causes a signicant level of disruption, fear and distress to our residents, which we deem unacceptable."Mr Rutherford has a long history of behaving in an anti-social manner which is why the council applied for this interim ASBO."We will take similar action against those who persist in behaving in an unacceptable way.The interim order will prevent Mr Rutherford from behaving in the manner described until November  when the case will call again.At that time, the council will ask the court to grant an ASBO in the same terms as the interim order but for a period of two years.

title: uk-needs-precise-framework-for-future-trade-to-agree-eu-withdrawal-deal-may
story: The Prime Minister was speaking a week ahead of a crunch Brussels summit on October -, at which it had initially been hoped the withdrawal deal would be finalised.But a deal next week remains far from certain, despite optimistic comments from senior EU figures over recent days, with Mrs May making clear that agreement has not yet been reached on the key issue of the Irish border.DUP leader Arlene Foster ndash whose MPs prop up the minority Conservative administration in the Commons ndash closed down one mooted avenue for compromise by insisting her party will not accept customs or regulatory checks on goods travelling in either direction between Northern Ireland and Great Britain.Reports had suggested that deadlock over the so-called ldquobackstop arrangements for Ireland could be broken by permitting checks on exports from the mainland to the north, but not in the opposite direction.ldquoThere cannot be any customs or regulatory barriers between ourselves and the rest of the United Kingdom, both ways, said Mrs Foster following talks with EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier in Brussels.ldquoItrsquos not just a case of regulations between Northern Ireland and GB, itrsquos also between GB and Northern Ireland. Wersquove made that very clear. The Prime Minister understands our position and I expect her to respect that position.Continuing discussions with Northern Irish political leaders today: @DUPleader, @DianeDoddsMEP  @RobinSwannUUP, @JNicholsonMEP. Working hard to explain and de-dramatise the backstop #Brexit pic JLWoQNYzGmdash Michel BarnierOctober , Mrs May told the regular weekly Cabinet meeting at  Downing Street that talks to finalise a withdrawal deal were continuing ldquoon an intensive basis.Her official spokesman said: ldquoThe PM said that our efforts will focus on seeking agreement on the few remaining issues, including the Northern Ireland backstop.ldquoShe made clear that we canrsquot agreed to a withdrawal agreement without a precise future framework which delivers the future trade and security partnership which the Government wants.ldquoThe PM said the UK would continue working hard in the talks on Brexit and the message from EU leaders is that they want to reach a deal.Meanwhile, the Prime Minister was warned that she faces a Commons rebellion of at least  Conservative MPsshe s from Brussels with a deal based on her Chequers plan, leaving the UK ldquohalf in, half out of the EU.A revolt on this scale would leave Mrs May relying on the votes of dozens of Labour MPs to secure parliamentary approval for any deal.Former Brexit minister Steve Baker said that as many as  Tories are ready to oppose the plan agreed by Cabinet at Mrs Mayrsquos country residence in July, and that at least half of them would stand firm against an ldquoextremely hard whipping operation.If you listened to the Brexit segment on @BBCrtoday and wanted more context, these  short videos may be helpful:https:t.co pAmALYpZPGet the transcripts here:https:t.co KgPRlWviuQ#PlanAPlusmdash Steve Baker MPOctober , Mr Baker, a senior figure in the hardline Brexiteer European Research Group, told BBC Radio rsquos Today programme: ldquoThe whips would be doing incredibly wellthey were to halve the numbers.ldquoMy estimate is that there are at least  colleagues who are not going to accept a half-in, half-out Chequers deal or indeed a backstop that leaves us in the internal market and the customs union, come what may.Conservative former chief whip Mark Harper warned that relying on Labour voters would not work.Mr Harper, who was a Home Office minister during Mrs Mayrsquos tenure in the department, told the Daily : ldquoWe are going to have to carry this deal on our own benches. If yoursquore the Prime Minister, you do have to listen to colleagues.International Development Secretary Penny Mordaunt, who campaigned for Leave in the referendum, said Mrs May ldquohas my support and I am not in any way expecting that situation to change.But she suggested that the Prime Minister may have to amend her Chequers plan to get a final deal, saying that ldquowe donrsquot know where this is going to end up.Answering questions following a speech in London, Ms Mordaunt said:ldquoThe Prime Minister can count on my support.ldquoBut what I would say is that we donrsquot know where this is going to end up. We are at a critical moment now. The ball is firmly back in the EUrsquos court. We are waiting for them to respond.

title: is-this-the-worlds-unhealthiest-pizza-glasgow-takeaway-launches-deep-fried-mars-bar-calzone
story: Described as a lsquoGlaswegian twistrsquo on the Italian food it is served with grated almonds on top of the pizza dough, caramel sauce and a scoop of chocolate ice cream.It is packed with Mars Bar chunks then cooked in batter and dubbed by locals as the Mars-gherita Pizza.With an estimated , calories packed into the snack, sold at Romans Pizzeria in Merchant City, Glaswegians have been flocking to try it.The takeaway is inspired by the notorious deep-fried Mars Bar treat invented in  at a Stonehaven, Aberdeenshire, chippy - Haven Chip Bar .Romanrsquos general manager, Fraser Walker, said the idea behind the deep fried Mars Bar calzone came from a simple conversation with the head chef.The -year-old, from Kelvindale, said: "Well the shop has been open here for about five and a half months and we wanted to bring out something dferent."This is because we are known for our Roman-style pizza, and after speaking to the chef about dferent ideas we came up with that."Weve seen restaurants adding Nutella in a calzone so we just thought the deep fried mars bar is a Scottish thing. title: pipers-to-mark-armistice-day
story: The musicians will pay tribute to the fallen on the centenary of the Armistice on November , playing When The Battles Over - the tune that was traditionally played by Scottish regiments at the end of a battle.The Battles Over event, which will see  pipers around the globe play the song at am on the day, is being organised by pageant master Bruno Peek who claims the event will be a "swathe of sound across the world", starting in New Zealand.Mr Peek said: "Itrsquos going to pay tribute to the millions who either died or ed home dreadfully wounded during or after the war finished on November  .ldquoI wanted to put together an international project that was led by the people of the world, not by governments or organisations but real community-based commemorations, because as we know so many soldiers that died came from local communities, small towns and parishes, not just in the UK but other countries around the world.The pipers will play in village greens and high streets, as well as more prominent locations, including the Tomb Of The Unknown Warrior at Westminster Abbey in London where a lone piper will play.The event will also see more than  buglers play The Last Post at inidual First World War beacon sites later that day at .pm, with the beacons being lit at pm to signy the light that came out of the darkness of war.More than  town criers will then undertake A Cry For Peace Around The World at .pm, and more than , churches will ring their bells as a finale to the day.Mr Peek said he has worked with town and parish councils and organisations around the world, sending emails from his home in Gorleston-on-Sea near Great Yarmouth, Norfolk, to bring his vision for a tribute to le.ldquoItrsquos been a long process, a lot of administration, but I feel so privileged to be working with so many people who want to pay tribute to those who gave so much so that we enjoy the freedom of speech and movement we have today, he said.He said many of the buglers were cadets, as ldquowe felt it really important to involve young people in these commemorations.The cry for peace will be led by a Cha Pensioner from the Royal Hospital, Cha.In Ypres in Belgium, where five battles were fought, four town criers will undertake the cry together in the market square in French, German, Dutch and English.To see a guide of where events are happening on the day and how to get involved, see www.brunopeek.Mr Peek said he wants to list all who are taking part in the guide, and the closing date to be included is October .

title: mark-smith-why-the-polls-arent-as-good-as-independence-supporters-think-they-are
story: But havenrsquot we been here before  In fact, Irsquom tempted to say wersquore stuck in a bit of a time loop on this one, with the same events happening over and over again. Nicola Sturgeon said on Sunday that support for independence was at historically high levels, but in early September  a YouGov poll showed support for yes at  per cent this weekendrsquos survey for The Sunday Times on the other hand shows that, even with a no-deal Brexit, support for independence would be lower than that, at  per cent. ldquoHistorically pretty much the same might be a better description.However, itrsquos worth taking a look again at exactly what the new polls say. The first one, by Survation, found that,there were an independence referendum tomorrow,  per cent would vote yes and  per cent no. Butthe UK leaves the EU as planned next year, that changes to  for yes and  for no ndash and it changes againtherersquos a no-deal, with  per cent backing yes and  per cent no. The other survey, by Panelbase, found a similar rise:the UK left the EU without a deal, support for independence would increase from  per cent in  to  per cent, while support for the Union would fall from  to .On the face of it, these look like encouraging figures for the SNP, with Brexit pushing support for independence in the right direction. ButI were a Scottish Government strategist, I might privately be a bit worried. In fact, I might even have suggested to my bosses that they keep quiet about the Survation poll, which was commissioned by the SNP, for the simple reason that it doesnrsquot show enough of what they need it to show.The problem is that the surveys do indeed appear to indicate support for the SNP and independence going up. But they also demonstrate something more disturbing for the party, which is that the expected Brexit effect on support for independence simply isnrsquot happening, or at least it isnrsquot happening to the extent that Nicola Sturgeon needs it to.This lack of a signicant Brexit bounce also emphasises the dilemmas faced by Ms Sturgeon. The party members who traipsed into the conference on Sunday and marched through Edinburgh on Saturday are nationalists because their heart tells them to be, but the First Minister takes a much more mathematical approach to the situation, led by the numbers and the probabilities.This is why we saw her shting her position on a second EU referendum at the weekend. The dficulty for Ms Sturgeon is that shersquos a declared supporter of the EU, but the very thing she appears to be fighting ndash Brexit ndash may also offer her the best chance of getting what she really wants: Scottish independence. This means she has to be careful not to fight Brexit too hard, and yet she can see that a consensus is building for a second EU referendum that it would look odd for the SNP to oppose. And so Sturgeon the mathematician nudges forward and says her MPs would support it in the Commons. Their leader there, Ian Blackford, gave the game away when he addressed the subject. ldquoWe will not obstruct a second vote on Brexit, he said ndash hardly the words of a passionate anti-Brexiteer.The weekendrsquos opinion polls throw up similar strategical problems on when to hold a second independence referendum. They do appear to show a small Brexit effect and, anecdotally, Irsquove noticed it among friends and family. Quite a few who voted no in  have told me, over a coffee , that Brexit means they might vote dferently next time. But a hypothetical vote in the pub, or indeed in an opinion poll, is not the same as the real thing, when all the old economic realities would come back. Indeed, they might be even more intense in a post-Brexit world with switherers asking themselves whether, having come out of one economic union , they want to risk coming out of another .The fact that the small rise in support for independence is based on these hypotheticals leaves Nicola Sturgeon with three equally risky options. The first is to call a referendum before the next Scottish elections in  but that would be rejected by Theresa May and probably even Jeremy Corbynhe were PM given the pressure he would face from his Scottish wing. The SNP might be able to gain some traction by fostering a grievance about the referendum being rejected in this way, but option one is essentially a dead end.The second option is one that no one expects to happen ndash a Catalan-style, unofficial referendum ndash but itrsquos the third ndash delay the referendum until after  - that is the most likely. The theory behind it, as far as some SNP strategists are concerned, is that this allows more time for Brexit to convert more no voters. The aim would also be to win the  election based on a promise to hold another independence referendum, which would make it impossible for a Prime Minister to say no.This is Nicola Sturgeonrsquos preferred option ndash she just hasnrsquot said it yet. Indeed, itrsquos never going to be easy for her to say it as long as thousands of nationalists are marching through Scottish cities. She also knows that delaying is risky ndash the Panelbase poll predicts that the independence-supporting parties will lose their majority in  there is also a danger that voters will simply get used to being outside the EU Brexit will become the new status quo.And then therersquos the awkward reality that, whatever your analysis of the new polls, there is still a working majority in Scotland opposed to independence. Ms Sturgeonrsquos gamble ndash as yet undeclared ndash is that this will change by . The problem is that, even in the face of a Tory-imposed Brexit, both sides in Scotlandlook pretty resistant to change.

title: letters-claims-that-article-50-can-keep-uk-in-eu-could-just-be-mischief-making
story: In July  the Convention on the Future of Europe produced its Draft Treaty. This contained Article  and was signed by the President and two Vice-Presidents who were mere figureheads and by the present Lord John Kerr, the Conventionrsquos Secretary General, who was responsible for its production.With a little adjustment it was presented to member states for ratication as The Treaty Establishing a Constitution for Europe. This was abandoned when referendums in France and the Netherlands produced negative votes. After ious modications and rearrangements together with repeated scrutiny by the EUrsquos own legal experts, the constitution emerged re-named The European Reform Treaty, better known as The Treaty of Lisbon. It is the definitive document governing EU legislation.There is no reference in any of these versions of the treaty to a reversal of notication by a member state that has announced its intention to withdraw from the European Union, except that, after leaving, it is permitted to apply to re-join under the usual conditions for new applicants.Although a group of Scottish politicians is perfectly entitled to require clarication by the European Court of Justice, that body is qualied only to interpret, not alter, laws a treaty is surely even more inviolable Brexit lsquolikely to succeedrsquo, The Herald, October . So why has Lord Kerr, who instigated Article  devised a second referendum described as a road map to a Peoplersquos Vote, for which a new clause would need to be inserted to provide for a unilateral withdrawal of notication and which would almost certainly require a new treaty and ratication by all other member states Immediately after the UK referendum, Prime Minister Theresa May was informed that cherry-picking was inadmissible. Soit is dficult to understand her motive for insisting on the Chequers Plan, it is even more dficult to discern Lord Kerrrsquos for including in Article  the condition of a negotiated agreement between the EU and the departing member state within a time limit ndash with or without extensions ndash and between two such unequally-matched participants.Since a member state has always been entitled to leave the EU, Article  appears to a non-expert to be a recipe for confusion and hostility and Lord Kerrrsquos recent political intervention with regard to the alteration of a treaty that he was largely instrumental in producing, is either a delaying tactic or simply mischief-making.Mary Rolls, Castlegate, Jedburgh.One might think from Mr Russellrsquos letterthat the Labour Party has been arguing for European Economic Areamembership since June , except its  manesto makes not a single reference to this. Certainly, it suggests Labour would have put in place ldquofresh negotiating priorities that have a strong emphasis on retaining the benefits of the single market and the customs union, which is fine, but probably what even Leave wanted just as long as we didnrsquot have to meet the obligations.Instead, Labour has six tests but they are packed full of warm words and uncertainty. One instance is the last test: ldquoDoes it deliver for all regions and nations of the UK . This is not a matter of Yes No, but ldquohow much does it deliver for the regions and nations of the UK  ldquois it enough  and ldquois it distributed equitably round the UK , which in turn beg questions about ldquoenough and ldquoequitably. There is so much wiggle-room in this ldquotest that it tells us nothing.But most risible of all is: ldquoDoes [an agreement] deliver the exact same benefits as we currently have as members of the Single Market and Customs Union , which can only mean that, despite no longer being members of the single market, or the customs union, we would continue to get the benefits we get now as members. If one thing has become clear during the Brexit negotiations, it is that the EU will only grant access in proportion to the degree to which we follow its rules, so the same benefits means approximately the same rules. However, as non-members, for instance in the EEA, we would have limited influence on how these rules evolve in the future.Lastly, Mr Russell asserts thatmore of us had voted for Ed Miliband in  the present shambles would have been avoided, but this is misleading in two regards. First, the  Labour manesto promised an in out referendumBrussels sought to transfer more powers to itself. Secondly, evenLabour had held all  of its Scottish seats rather than only one, it would still have been  seats short of a majority.Alasdair Galloway, Silverton Avenue, Dumbarton.I AGREE with Peter R Russell that a Brexit deal to trade through the European Free Trade Agreementand the European Economic Areaseems the only way through the political quagmire we are in. Is it doable, though  Labour has no genuine positions on Brexit and appears as likely to split as the Tories are.But Peter Russell argues that Scotland should have no constitutional option other than trail along the same path as is decreed by whomever is in power at Westminster. Given the indference to Scottish sensibilities on Brexit by both Labour and Tory parties, that is a bit rich. Peter Russell also referenced Ed Miliband, who stated during the EU referendum that a dferential vote on Brexit would could lead to the end of the Union. Scotland has had no leverage whatsoever on negotiations, no participation, no recognition or status for our national interests.Why would we find that an acceptable situation to be in  My preference is for a self-governing Scotland to trade with the EU, through Efta and the EEA, maintaining our fishing grounds and commerce with the rUK: the best of all worlds.GR Weir, Mill Street, Ochiltree.THERESA Mayrsquos playground jibe at the Nicola Sturgeonrsquos aim to remain in the single market and customs union as betrayal is to forget several points. Scotland voted to remain. The democratic voice of Scots is being silenced by Westminster. As to a betrayal of Scots fishermen, the acceptance of the Common Fisheries Policy was a cave-in by Edward Heath. A renegotiated policy by a future Holyrood government would not disadvantage Scots fishing industry. Strange that Mrs May was a Remain supporter in !!John Edgar, a Langmuir Quadrant, Kilmaurs.

title: lovely-jubbly-musical-version-of-only-fools-and-horses-created
story: The creator of the long-running sitcom died aged  in , before work on a musical retelling of the Trotters misadventures could be completed.His son Jim has partnered with comedy writer Paul Whitehouse to pen Only Fools And Horses The Musical and fulfil his fathers wishes for a stage production.The show took five years to complete and features an original score which includes contributions from Hodges, who died in September.Whitehouse told the Press Association the feel-good stage show aims to protect the legacy of the BBC series, which first aired in .He said: "It was John Sullivans project, and it was what he was writing when he very tragically died."I spoke with Chas Hodges about doing some stuff with this. Sadly Chas is gone now as well."So it is a delicate legacy. Especially for Jim. I think he set out to finish what his father had started."Only Fools wasnt just a comedy show, it became part of peoples lives."We want to celebrate John Sullivans writing, and hope weve done it justice."Whitehouse said the show now has the added responsibility of honouring Hodges work, after the Chas  Dave musician died of pneumonia aged .The Fast Show writer said: "Chas and I both got on, we grew up in the same area. We both support Spurs. We went fishing in the same spots. We really got close."Its been a labour of love. There is a lot of responsibility."The musical features elements from the whole series, centred around Del Boy, Rodney and Grandad.Whitehouse has taken the role of the elderly patriarch, with Tom Bennett as Del Boy and Ryan Hutton as Rodney.Supporting characters such as Boycie, Trigger, Raquel and Cassandra will also feature in the adaptation.Jim Sullivan said: "Writing the musical was a big challenge. The world of Only Fools is so rich with characters and history it spanned over two decades and included births, deaths and marriages."We wanted to stay faithful to the original material as much as possible, but without simply regurgitating it."As well as honouring the TV series, the show also aims to comment on a changing London.Whitehouse said: "Everyone is a millionairethey own a house in Peckham now. You have to be."The stage show starts its run at the Theatre Royal Haymarket in February .

title: scotlands-45bn-uk-export-market-is-a-weakness-says-snp-msp
story: Joan McAlpine said Scotland was too reliant on one ldquocustomer and should learn from Irelandrsquos experience.She said Ireland used to send  per cent of its exports to the UK, but this hadfallen to just % as trade with the European Union boomed.Pamela Nash, chief executive of anti-independence group Scotland in Union, said the comments would "stun businesses across Scotland".Ms McAlpine, who is the convener of Holyroodrsquos culture, tourism, Europe and external affairs committee, was speaking at a fringe meeting at the SNPrsquos autumn conference.She said: ldquoIf you were a business and most of your trade was with one customer, you wouldnrsquot see that as a strength mdash you would see that as a weakness.ldquoYou want to be erse and have as many customers as possible.ldquoThatrsquos whatrsquos happened with Irelandrsquos membership of the EU, without damaging its trade withthe UK.ldquoAnd thatrsquos what could happen to Scotland as well, in my view.ldquoAnd I think thatrsquos a point that we should be making more and perhaps will make more in the coming months and years.Scotland exported more than pound billion in goods and services to England, Wales and Northern Ireland in . Exports to the EU totalled pound.bn.Ms McAlpine said the UK struggled with the fact Ireland ldquocalls the shots in the current Brexit negotiations, insisting it still has a ldquocolonial mentality towards the country.She made the comments during a discussion of ldquoindependence in Europe, in which she also argued Spain would not veto Scotlandrsquos future membership of the EUit broke away from the UK.Critics have previously argued Spain would stand in the way of an independent Scotland joining the blocto avoid fuelling separatist movements in Catalonia.The South Scotland MSP said last yearrsquos failed Catalonian referendum illustrated the EU ldquowill go to the wall for a member state.But she added: ldquoThe UK is not going to be a member state when Scotland applies to join as an independent country, so itrsquos going to be completely dferent.ldquoThe UK, after March next year, will not have any clout in Europe whatsoever. So I donrsquot think that will happen.SNP MEP Alyn Smith said Spain had made clear aScottish independence vote with the agreement of the UK would not be a problem.But he said nothing could be taken for granted and EU membership would not be automatic.Ms Nash said being part of the UK was key to Scotlands economic growth, generating thousands of jobs and boosting revenues.She said: "The fact that Joan McAlpine considers this to be a weakness shows how little she cares about the impact on peoples livelihoods in the persuit of independence at all costs."

title: second-brexit-vote-not-a-precedent-for-indy-says-nicola-sturgeon
story: After saying SNP MPs would back a Peoplersquos Vote on the Brexit dealit came to a choice in the Commons, the First Minister said the situation was quite dferentfor independence.The Scottish Tories accused her of ldquorank hypocrisy.Senior SNP figures including former deputy leader Jim Sillars and former cabinet secretary Alex Neil have warned against a second vote on Brexit in case it sets a precedent for a Unionist-led ldquothird referendum on independence to overturn a Yes vote.But Ms Sturgeon said the EU and UK constitutional votes were not alike, as there was no detailed prospectus on Brexit but there was a detailed White Paper on independence in .On the issue of another vote on Brexit, the First Minister told BBC Radio Scotland: "If the vote presents itself in the House of Commons - I dont know yet that it will - my view is that SNP MPs should vote for that."Asked whether that would then a precedent for on independence, Ms Sturgeon replied: "In my view, no, and Ill explain exactly why."She said: "If you look back to , there was a detailed proposition put to people in that referendum, the White Paper, which not everybody agreed with, obviously."It was a detailed proposition, setting out the implications, setting out in advance some of the compromises that would be required - currency union, for example, continued regulatory harmony."So people knew what they were voting for. They knew the shape of the deal that the Scottish Government would then have negotiatedthe vote had been for independence."The contrast between that and the  Brexit vote could not be starker. There was the lie on the side of the bus and nothing more."There was no detail then, there is no detail now and it looks increasingly likely that when the UK leaves the EU at the end of March next year, there will still be no detail about the future relationship, and that makes these two situations, in my view, very dferent."She repeated the point when asked about a future White Paper merely being a starting point in negotiations with the UK, and not the final outcome, which might be quite dferent.In , the White Paper said Scotland would be able to continue in a currency union with sterling, but the UK government explicitly ruled it out.Glasgow Tory MSP Annie Wells said: ldquoSurely even Nicola Sturgeon can see the rank hypocrisy here.ldquoHer position is that,she loses a referendum, then it must be re-run ndash butshe wins one, we have to accept her say-so forever.ldquoWe may be Leave or Remain, Yes or No, but we should all be democrats first and foremost. That means respecting our decision to stay in the UK, and respecting our decision to leave the EU.ldquoNicola Sturgeonrsquos failure to do either speaks volumes about her failure to listen. With an attitude like this, no wonder the SNP lost  seats under her leadership last year.

title: mp-tells-snp-not-to-dither-over-indyref2
story: In a coded swipe at the First Minister, Angus Brendan MacNeil said Brexit had created an opportunity for independence ldquohere and now, but the window was limited.He said the SNP would have to consider an alternative routethe UK government refused to allow a legally binding vote through a so-called Section  order.He said: ldquoIf we canrsquot make this under a Section  order, we have to make it another way.ldquoThe SNP has always rejected a unilateral referendum of the kind held in Catalonia, as it would not be legally binding and would be likely to end up mired in a court dispute.Mr MacNeilrsquos comments followed MP Joanna Cherry QC claiming that independence could be delivered through a ldquodemocratic event such as an election, not a referendum.Both Mr MacNeil and Ms Cherryrsquos comments are at odds with the official SNP line, which is that the referendum of  was the ldquogold standard for any future decision.However the pair also reflect the frustration in the party about the increasingly slim chance chance of Theresa May or any another British PM granting a second referendum.Mr MacNeil told delegates there was an opportunity ldquohere and now for independence because of Brexit and the window would last until the next Holyrood election in .He said the SNP must not ldquodither like the Jacobite army which got as far south as Derby as it marched on London in , then gave up and turned back.Mr MacNeil, the MP for the Western Isles, said: ldquoWe have to be very cognisant of the fact that the opportunity for independence that is arising at the moment because of Brexit.ldquoIt is not needed to wait for a generation or whatever, the opportunity is here and now.ldquoBecause despite our best efforts of trying to keep the United Kingdom within the European Union, trying to keep the United Kingdom within the customs union and the single market, they have steamed onwards, the Tory government, for the clf, as fast as they can.ldquoBut we have a -month window to do something about it. We cannot know the exact timinghellip but we do know the window is likely to be March  to March .ldquoIf we canrsquot make this under a Section  order, we have to make it another way.ldquoWe cannot dither at this point. We cannot be like the Jacobites in Derby and let the opportunity pass as it did in  and  for them. We have to move forward.ldquoIndependence is on  to % and you ainrsquot seen nothing yet by the time we get going.He added: ldquoAs Theresa May said of the UK, we joined as nation states and we therefore must be free as a nation state to make the choice to leave.ldquoWell, Theresa May,that applies to the UK and the European Union, it most certainly applies to Scotland in the United Kingdom.Pamela Nash, chief executive of the pro-UK Scotland in Union group, said: "This is yet more evidence that the SNP is determined to ignore the views of Scotland in its relentless pursuit of independence.ldquoPeople dont want a isive and unnecessary second independence referendum, so senior SNP figures are desperately trying to find a dangerous alternative route to independence. Their obsession is incredibly damaging for the country, and its time the SNP got back to the day job.ldquoNicola Sturgeon must be in despair at the ridiculous comments being made by her parliamentarians at this conference.Mr MacNeilrsquos remarks came in spite of Nicola Sturgeon being forced to restate her partyrsquos commitment to the referendum process used in .On Sunday, SNP MP Joanna Cherry said a ldquodemocratic event such as a general election could be enough to deliver independence, and there need not be a referendum.Asked whether she agreed with Ms Cherry, Ms Sturgeon told BBC Radio Scotland: ldquoMy view is, as it has always been, that the people of Scotland will decide the question of independence in a referendum. Thats the party position, that remains the party position."But she continued: "In defence of Joanna, I think its a bit rich for the opposition to have a go at SNP members for speculating about how we might be able to express our views on independence in circumstances where, in a fundamentally anti-democratic fashion, we have got opposition parties suggesting that they would block the ability to choose in a referendum."

title: five-fold-spike-in-workers-taking-employers-to-tribunal
story: More than , extra cases were lodged in the first six months of this year compared to the same period in  - prompting claims the tribunal service is becoming "overwhelmed" by the influx.The fee regime, which saw employees paying up to pound to lodge a case, was scrapped in July last year following a Supreme Court ruling that the charges were unlawful and unfair.Since then claims have been pouring in, with single claimsin Scotland increasing from  to , - a rise of more than  per cent.Trade union UNISON, which led the fight against the fees at the Supreme Court, said the increase showed just how vital free access to justice is for workers.Peter Hunter, of UNISON Scotland, said: "The rise in tribunal cases is evidence of the importance of UNISONs historic win over the Tory government."Work can be unfair and workers need free access to justice. On top of that, most of the additional cases in Scotland are equal pay and we are right down the middle of that - rooting out discrimination."The rise in equal pay cases is particularly appropriate since it was equal pay in Dumfries  Galloway that the Supreme Court used as an example of how free access to justice for one worker seeking pay equality brings benefit for many thousands."The judges were right in their analysis back in  and this data shows how big landmark cases reverberate in workplaces across the entire country."When the fees were introduced in July , The Herald reported a drop in cases of almost  per cent year on year.This prompted claims from employment experts that thousands of workers, especially women, who had been unfairly sacked or discriminated against, were being denied access to justice.The current figures from the UK Government show a complete turnaround, with equal pay cases - including a large scale claim against Glasgow City Council - accounting for the bulk of the cases with an increase of  per cent.Unfair dismissal claims also increased by  per cent over the period, while sex discrimination claims went up by almost  per cent and disability discrimination claims almost doubled.Brian McLaughlin, an employment lawyer with Unionline Scotland, which represents members of the GMB and Communications Workers Union, said: "This is a signicant increase which is obviously welcomed by Unionline Scotland and the GMB and CWU trade unions."These fees were a barrier to justice which created a signicant problem for unfairly treated employees for the best part of four years."This upsurge in cases shows that the fees were a clear denial of access to justice."Jim Stephenson, convener of the Law Society of Scotlandrsquos Access to Justice committee, added that the increase showed "a very real need for an accessible, impartial system to resolve workplace disputes".While David Martyn, an employment specialist with Thompsons solicitors, claimed that the fees proved to be a "massive disincentive" for workers."For someone who was only claiming say pound, and having to pay out pound in upfront fees, the risk to reward ratio really didnt make any economic sense," he said.He also claimed that the scrapping of the fees has had a "signicant impact" on the employment tribunal service in Scotland, which he described as "stretched".A total of  new judges have been appointed in Scotland to meet the increased demand for hearings, while several tribunal rooms at the main hearing centre in Glasgow, which were converted into office space while the fee regime was in place, have had to be reinstated.Mr Martyn said: "The tribunal service is struggling to cope, it was almost inevitable when the fees were stopped. The staff are doing their very best but theyre certainly stretched."These concerns were echoed by employment specialist Stephen Miller, of Clyde  Co, who claimed the tribunal service "has been overwhelmed by the numbers".He added that the increase in claims would also result in businesses and organisations facing signicant costs in defending the actions.

title: scots-councils-invest-20m-to-modernise-library-service
story: The Scottish Library and Information Councilsaid the investment showed the strong commitment of councils to public library services.Earlier this month, figures showed a dramatic increase in the Secretary for Culture, Tourism and External Affairs, welcomed the investment - announced in Libraries Week.She said: ldquoThis week celebrates the vital role of our libraries in Scotland and the fantastic service provided by staff and volunteers.ldquoI welcome this yearrsquos focus on wellbeing, which fits in well with the Scottish Governmentrsquos commitment to promoting social wellbeing and
